Modern data-intensive applications, such as analytics platforms, monitoring tools, and high performance computing workloads, face significant scalability challenges due to memory constraints. Traditional distributed shared memory (DSM) solutions remain complex, insecure, and inefficient, while existing remote storage mechanisms fail to meet the latency and flexibility needs of in-memory workloads. To address these limitations, this study proposes Memory-as-a Service (

) — a secure, scalable, and low-latency architecture for disaggregated memory. The proposed system introduces a pluggable daemon and SDK framework that enables seamless integration with diverse applications via flexible APIs (e.g.,
, QUIC, Go, and Rust SDKs). Centralized lifecycle management ensures robust quota allocation, encryption, and observability, making

adaptable for multi-tenant environments. A proof-of-concept implementation with Prometheus demonstrates compatibility and performance gains, while the architecture remains extensible to databases, machine learning platforms, and streaming engines. By overcoming challenges of latency, security, modularity, and integration,
paves the way for efficient memory scaling in next-generation cloud and analytics infrastructures.
Defines how Prometheus communicates with the external Rust backend (Config API).
Refers to the primary hardware component responsible for executing Prometheus and backend workloads.
A concept related to shared remote memory systems, underlying the architecture inspiration for the Rust backend design.
Communication framework used for exchange between Prometheus and Rust backend for memory operations.
Represents Grafana’s user interface for backend configuration, metric visualization, and system monitoring.
Basic underlying web protocol used for service discovery and auxiliary endpoints in Prometheus.
(If referenced in report contextually) Refers to adaptive intelligence modules studied conceptually for system automation or inference (not part of base implementation).
Security protocol ensuring encrypted, authenticated communication between Prometheus and the backend.
Hosting environment for both Prometheus and the Rust backend daemon (typically Linux).
Language for querying metrics data from Prometheus and visualizing results through Grafana.
Underlying transport layer protocol optimizing latency and throughput for
Local system memory that Prometheus extends using the remote Rust-based backend.
Mechanism used by Prometheus to request data operations from the backend service.
The document describing software scope, architecture, and behavior for this Prometheus extension project.
Cryptographic protocol ensuring secure communication over networks.
Prometheus’s native database that stores metric samples indexed by time and labels.
Frontend visualization layer (Grafana) used for user interaction and configuration management.
File format used for defining Prometheus configuration and backend connection parameters.
Modern applications generate increasingly large and complex datasets, often exhausting local RAM resources and limiting scalability. In emerging disaggregated data

, compute and memory resources are expected to scale independently. However, current approaches—particularly distributed shared memory (DSM) solutions—are often too complex, unsafe, and lack proper observability. Existing remote or secondary storage options do not meet the low-latency and flexibility needs of memory-intensive workloads, especially for demanding systems like Prometheus, which rely heavily on fast in-memory operations for time series data.

The core aim of this project is to design and implement a safe, high-performance, and transparent remote memory service that can serve as an extension to Prometheus's native RAM operations. Specific objectives include:
Building a pluggable remote RAM backend offering memory allocate, deallocate, read, and write operations over efficient transports (
Enabling seamless integration between Prometheus and the backend via a dedicated Config API, so configuration and connectivity can be managed easily through a user-facing frontend such as Grafana.
Demonstrating real-world compatibility and measurable performance improvements, validating the design by integrating with Prometheus as a proof-of-concept.
Ensuring the final system is modular, secure, and observable, guaranteeing robust operation, traceability, and ease of adoption for diverse environments.

The report begins by introducing the motivation and objectives of integrating an external memory backend with Prometheus. It then reviews related work and the limitations of current DSM and time series solutions. The system architecture section describes the overall design, components, and data flows.
Implementation details are presented for both the modified Prometheus core and the Rust backend daemon.
Following this, the report summarizes key evaluation findings and observed improvements.
It ends with a discussion of potential extensions and concluding remarks.

The movement towards disaggregated memory in modern computing seeks to decouple compute and memory resources for enhanced scalability and efficiency. Chen, Li, and Kumar (2024) conducted a comprehensive survey covering cross-layer techniques and hardware taxonomies such as CXL, Gen-Z, and RDMA, and also examined OS/runtime and application-level strategies for remote and far memory[Chen et al., 2024]. They highlighted key trade-offs involving latency, bandwidth, and programmability, noting programmability bottlenecks and substantial complexity as open challenges. However, their review was limited to broad perspectives, providing a taxonomy but no concrete implementation or evaluation of working systems.

Recent work brings focus to the system-level addressing of these design challenges. Zhang, Patel, and Venkataraman (2025) explored operator and OS/runtime-level coherence management for pooled CXL shared memory[Zhang et al., 2025]. Their solution combined adaptive hardware/software policies for fine-grained memory sharing, yielding efficient coherence but at the cost of architectural complexity and with comparably limited portability. This highlights ongoing technical barriers to deploying pooled memory in a manner that is both effective and broadly applicable.
Wang, Kim, and Lee (2025) introduced Beehive, an asynchronous runtime for disaggregated memory that dynamically transforms synchronous threads into fine-grained coroutines ("

"). This Rust-based system integrates locality-aware memory management and is shown to scale across up to 24 servers, delivering notable gains in latency hiding and overall throughput[Wang et al., 2025]. Their approach demonstrates 1.5–4× speedups over previous systems but requires invasive code changes and is limited to Rust-based workloads, indicating a trade-off between efficiency and universality.

At the OS level, Liu, Tang, and Arpaci-Dusseau (2023) proposed Canvas, a framework providing isolated and adaptive remote memory swapping for multi-tenant clouds[Liu et al., 2023]. Canvas uses per-application swap partitions and adaptive two-tier prefetching, achieving fairness and up to 6.2× faster swap performance under contention. While highly effective for fairness and performance within swap-focused scenarios, Canvas does not address the broader need for generic memory pooling or in-process shared memory, and its performance boosts are less significant when contention is low.
Safety and concurrency are critical in distributed shared memory (DSM). Singh, Müller, and Zhou (2024) present

, a DSM approach leveraging Rust’s ownership and borrow-checker model to ensure correct concurrency and memory usage at compile time[Singh et al., 2024]. The system provides low overhead and near-native speed, with object and thread placement techniques to maintain data locality. However,
is suitable only for Rust projects and poses barriers for legacy or multi-language codebases due to strict type-level checks and integration demands.

On the hardware side, Li, Wei, and Nelson (2021) created Concordia, which uses programmable switches and in-network cache coherence mechanisms for distributed memory systems[Li et al., 2021]. By managing hybrid metadata and performing adaptive ownership migration, Concordia achieves low-latency and high-throughput DSM, but requires custom switch hardware and introduces extra coordination challenges, limiting real-world scalability.

Collectively, these works underscore the explosive growth in remote and disaggregated memory research, driven by the limits of local RAM and the complexity of modern applications like Prometheus. While advancements in both hardware (e.g., CXL, in-network cache coherence) and software (e.g., Beehive, Canvas,

) have each addressed specific portions of the scalability, observability, or safety problem space, gaps remain in modularity, portability, ease of integration, and support for high-level application frameworks. Notably, none of the surveyed solutions offer a Prometheus-ready framework for integrating remote memory as a seamless extension of its native data processing paths, particularly with an emphasis on programmability and user-transparent configuration.

The key stakeholders include system administrators and DevOps engineers who manage Prometheus deployments, developers extending the Prometheus platform, users relying on real-time monitoring, platform architects designing scalable solutions, and security teams responsible for safe integrations. The Rust backend server team is crucial as they build and maintain the external memory service ensuring performance and safety.

Prometheus memory constraints and collecting inputs from monitoring teams and Prometheus contributors. Feedback emphasized seamless integration, low latency, and transparency. Additionally, the Rust backend team defined requirements for a concurrent-safe, efficient API service capable of handling memory allocation, deallocation, and data streaming via

The requirement specification defines the expected behavior, interactions, and performance of the Prometheus–External Memory Integration System. These are categorized into Functional and Non-Functional Requirements.
The Prometheus instance shall connect to an external Rust-based memory backend using a dedicated Config API.
The Config API shall allow configuration updates dynamically without requiring Prometheus restart.
Secure connectivity shall be established via
over QUIC to ensure low-latency and reliable data exchange.
The Prometheus instance shall invoke backend APIs to allocate and release memory segments remotely.
Each allocated memory block shall be associated with unique metric identifiers to ensure proper referencing.
The backend shall manage concurrent allocation requests using safe Rust concurrency
images shall be automatically saved for reference or retraining.
Prometheus shall perform read and write operations on time-series data residing in the external backend.
The backend shall maintain data integrity during remote reads and writes, even under concurrent Prometheus queries.
schemas with Snappy compression for performance optimization.
Prometheus shall treat external memory data equivalently to local in-memory data for query evaluation.
Queried time-series data shall be fetched on demand via the backend to maintain real-time metric availability.
Data retrieval shall be optimized with chunk-level caching and revalidation mechanisms.
Grafana shall serve as the UI interface for setting up backend connections and monitoring metrics.
The user shall view, edit, or remove configurations from the Grafana-integrated panel connected via the Config API.
Configuration changes shall propagate immediately to update Prometheus connectivity and backend load behavior.
The Rust backend shall support scalable concurrent operations using asynchronous runtimes such as Tokio.
The system shall handle a minimum of 10,000 time-series operations per second without degradation.
The backend shall support horizontal scaling to handle growing Prometheus data workloads.
API endpoints shall remain stateless to facilitate load balancing across multiple backend instances.
Future integrations (e.g., multi-node Prometheus or cloud setups) shall require minimal reconfiguration.
The backend shall employ Rust’s ownership model for safety, preventing data races and memory leaks.
The system shall ensure data consistency and handle transient failures via retries with exponential backoff.
Crash recovery mechanisms shall reconstruct state using checkpoints or transaction logs.
All API communications shall be encrypted via mutual TLS (
Authentication tokens or certificates shall be validated before allowing Prometheus–backend communication.
Sensitive data in logs or memory shall be masked before persistence.
Prometheus and the Rust backend shall expose internal health metrics via HTTP endpoints for observability
Logs shall record allocation size, operation type, latency, and connection status for traceability.
) shall support cross-component latency monitoring and debugging.
The SRS (Software Requirement Specification) Document was documented and verified. Several updates were made to SRS based on decisions made by the project team in agile scrum meetings.
User-facing control plane for configuring Prometheus’ remote memory behavior and viewing metrics/health.
Talks to the Config API on the modified Prometheus instance.
endpoint to accept configuration changes (backend endpoints, quotas, policies) and apply them at runtime.
Prometheus Core (extended): Native Prometheus process augmented with logic to:
Trigger remote memory operations when memory pressure or policy requires.
Perform dual-write (local TSDB + remote backend) or offload older/less-frequently-used series to the backend.
Proxy queries to local TSDB or to the remote backend for remote reads.
Provides the Memory-as-a-Service: Allocate / Deallocate / Read / Write operations.
Built in Rust for safety and performance (Tokio + Tonic suggested).
Manages concurrency, storage layout, caching, and persistence/checkpointing.
over QUIC between Prometheus and Rust backend (low-latency, multiplexed, connection migration-friendly).
Payload optimization: Snappy compression applied to time-series payloads as needed.
for mutual authentication; optionally OAuth2 for token-based auth at the application layer.
Stateless RPC endpoints: keep RPCs idempotent where possible to ease retries and load-balancing.
Memory policies (when to offload, retention/eviction rules, quota per metric).
Validates config and performs health-checks of listed backends before marking them active.
Decision logic: When local memory pressure or policy triggers offload, the Prometheus core:
Packs time-series blocks into remote-storage-friendly chunks.
Calls Allocate on the backend to reserve space (with metric ID and metadata).
Issues Write RPCs to stream chunks to the backend (possibly concurrently).
Keeps local index entries pointing to remote segments.
Dual-write mode: On ingestion, optionally write both to local TSDB and to backend to ensure redundancy and read availability.
If a requested range is remote-only or partially remote, Prometheus issues Read RPCs to fetch relevant chunks, merges with local data and returns query result seamlessly.
Metadata: Each allocated block is associated with:
Allocate: Reserve logical segments, return segment IDs and accepted metadata. May perform capacity checks and quota enforcement.
Write: Accept chunked writes (streaming RPC), store to fast media (RAM,
), update index, compute checksums, optionally persist to durable store or log.
Read: Return requested chunk(s). Support range queries, chunk-level caching, and de-duplication.
Deallocate: Free segments, trigger garbage collection, update quotas and metrics.
Concurrency: Use async runtimes and Rust concurrency primitives (no data races). Handle many parallel writes/reads.
Recovery: Periodic checkpoints or write-ahead logs to reconstruct state after crash.
User configures backend endpoints and policy in Grafana UI.
Grafana calls Prometheus Config API → Prometheus validates and establishes secure
Prometheus health-checks backends (TLS handshake, test RPC).
Prometheus decides to offload a metric block.
Backend stores chunk, returns ack + checksum/version.
Prometheus updates local index to reference remote
User issues a query that touches a remote segment.
Prometheus sees remote reference and calls Read(
Backend returns required chunks; Prometheus merges them with any local data, performs aggregation, and returns final result.
Prometheus decides to release a segment (policy or retention).
) → backend frees storage and updates metadata.

Chen, Y., Li, Z., & Kumar, R. (2024). Survey of Disaggregated Memory: Cross-layer Technique and Implementation. [Survey of hardware (CXL, Gen-Z, RDMA), OS/runtime, and application techniques for remote/far memory.]

Zhang, H., Patel, D., & Venkataraman, S. (2025). Rethinking Applications' Address Space with CXL Shared Memory Pools. In SoCC. [Adaptive OS/runtime coherence with pooled CXL memory; hybrid hardware/software policies.]

Wang, J., Kim, S., & Lee, J. (2025). Beehive: An Asynchronous Runtime for Disaggregated Memory. In NSDI ’25. [Rust-based async runtime for disaggregated memory with coroutines and locality-aware management.]

Liu, Y., Tang, H., & Arpaci-Dusseau, A. (2023). Canvas: Isolated and Adaptive Remote Memory Swapping for Multi-tenant Clouds. In NSDI ’23. [OS-level adaptive remote memory swapping with per-app partitioning.]
Singh, R., Müller, L., & Zhou, X. (2024).
: Distributed Shared Memory with Rust’s Ownership Types. In OSDI ’24. [Safe DSM with Rust ownership types enforcing concurrency correctness.]
Li, F., Wei, J., & Nelson, T. (2021). Concordia: In-network Cache Coherence for Distributed Shared Memory. In FAST ’21. [In-network cache coherence via programmable switches for DSM.]
Prometheus Authors. (2024). Prometheus Official Documentation: Storage and Remote Storage Integrations.
Grafana Labs. (2024). Grafana Official Documentation. https://grafana.com/docs/

This document specifies the detailed software requirements for integrating an external Rust-based memory backend with the Prometheus monitoring system. The objective is to create a scalable, secure, and highly efficient system that extends Prometheus’s native in-memory processing capabilities by transparently offloading time series data operations to a distributed, remote memory backend. The solution aims to enhance memory scalability without compromising Prometheus’s real-time querying and data processing performance.

The system enables Prometheus to dynamically offload time series data processing and storage from local memory to a remote Rust backend using a dedicated, secure Config API. Communication between Prometheus and the backend is carried over high-performance, low-latency

with QUIC transport. Users primarily interact with the system via Grafana, which provides intuitive configuration management, monitoring dashboards, and alerting interfaces for the integrated setup. This integration is designed to maintain backward compatibility with existing Prometheus deployments, ensuring minimal disruption during adoption.
Prometheus: An open-source monitoring and alerting toolkit widely used for recording time series data and evaluating queries in real-time environments.
Rust Backend: An external, distributed service implemented in Rust, providing safe, efficient remote memory allocation, read, write, and deallocation capabilities.
Config API: A runtime interface that manages the Prometheus–backend connection settings, allowing dynamic updates without promoting system restarts.

facilitates remote procedure calls via a strongly-typed, contract-first interface defined using Protocol Buffers, and QUIC provides low-latency, multiplexed transport with improved congestion control and security over UDP.

Grafana: A popular open-source analytics and monitoring platform providing the user interface for configuring backend connectivity, visualizing performance metrics, and managing operational alerts within the Prometheus ecosystem.

The proposed solution adopts a hybrid, disaggregated architecture that extends Prometheus beyond its traditional single-node, RAM-bound limits by seamlessly integrating a Rust-based remote memory backend. Prometheus retains its core functionalities, including metric scraping, time series storage, and

-based querying, while offloading memory-intensive operations to the external backend. Unlike conventional remote write/read storage, which only provides persistence or long-term retention, this design enables live memory augmentation, allowing Prometheus to treat remote memory as an extension of its active storage.

Internally, Prometheus continues to scrape metrics from exporters and store them temporarily in its in-memory head block before persisting to the TSDB. The new architecture introduces a Config API layer that enables Prometheus to interface dynamically with the remote backend daemon over

with QUIC, ensuring efficient serialization and secure, multiplexed data streaming. The Rust backend acts as a concurrent, fault-tolerant memory manager capable of allocating, deallocating, reading, and writing memory segments as requested, effectively functioning as a pluggable remote memory layer for Prometheus.
Dynamic Connectivity: The system allows real-time management of connections between Prometheus and the external memory backend via the Config API, with zero operational downtime.
Remote Memory Management: Supports remote allocation, deallocation, and read/write operations over
APIs defined using Protocol Buffers. The backend handles concurrency using Rust’s ownership and borrow semantics
Grafana Integration: Provides user-friendly dashboards for configuration, live monitoring of memory status, and operational analytics without direct backend interaction.
Secure Communication: All inter-service communications use mutual TLS authentication and QUIC transport encryption, ensuring data privacy, low latency, and resilience to packet loss.
Operational Observability: Detailed telemetry, structured logging, and
traces offer deep insight into Prometheus–backend interactions, enabling efficient debugging and performance optimization.
Configure, deploy, and maintain Prometheus instances with external backend integration for scaling metric ingestion and querying.
Manage backend configurations, monitor system performance, and ensure continuous uptime of the monitoring setup.
Develop and maintain the remote memory service daemon, ensuring low latency, concurrency safety, and stable
Design large-scale monitoring systems leveraging disaggregated architectures, integrating Prometheus with distributed compute or memory clusters
Users are expected to possess intermediate knowledge of Prometheus configuration,
APIs, and network-based observability tools like Grafana.
Backend service must be implemented in Rust to leverage safe concurrency and memory guarantees.
over QUIC to optimize latency and throughput.
Compatibility with existing Prometheus environments with minimal disruption.
Operational under standard networking infrastructure without requiring specialized hardware
The system leverages Grafana as the primary user interface for managing the backend memory integration with Prometheus. The Grafana-based UI components provide:
Configuration management panels to add, modify, or remove backend memory service connections dynamically without requiring system restarts.
Status monitoring dashboards displaying real-time metrics such as backend memory usage, allocation counts, read/write latencies, and connection health.
Alerting and notification integration allowing users to set thresholds and receive alerts related to backend performance issues or failures.
Query visualization tools that help users correlate Prometheus queries against remote memory statistics, enhancing observability and troubleshooting capabilities.
This design ensures operational teams and developers have intuitive, interactive access to critical system health and configuration controls.
The system communicates over standard network interfaces using TCP and UDP protocols supporting
over the QUIC transport layer. This setup enables:
Low-latency, reliable, and secure communication between Prometheus and the external Rust backend memory daemon.
and cloud networking infrastructure without requiring specialized hardware.
Scalability to support multi-node and distributed deployments where backend instances can be horizontally scaled.
The network interfaces are designed to accommodate high throughput and concurrent request processing while ensuring minimal packet loss or retransmission.
The integration between Prometheus and the Rust backend is implemented through a
API that governs all remote memory operations. This API defines:
Methods for memory allocation and deallocation requests, ensuring safe and efficient resource management on the backend.
Read and write operation endpoints allowing Prometheus to transparently access time series data stored off-host.
Protocol Buffers schemas with snappy compression to optimize serialization and minimize network bandwidth.
Integration hooks within Prometheus’s internal TSDB modules to route relevant calls to the remote backend without disrupting native operation paths.
Security layers interfacing with mutual TLS (
) authentication modules to enforce encrypted and verified communication.
Robust versioning and schema evolution support are built-in to facilitate backward compatibility and future feature extensions.

The Config API serves as the dynamic interface allowing Prometheus to manage its linkage to the external Rust-based memory backend without requiring service restarts. This interface supports adding, removing, and updating backend configurations in real time, ensuring zero downtime during operational changes. Internally, it manages connection lifecycle, authentication credentials, and health-checks while exposing endpoints that can be called either through Grafana UI or command-line tooling. The API is designed to be extensible for future enhancements like multi-backend support and load balancing.

At the core of the system, the Rust backend implements essential remote memory operations: allocation, deallocation, data reading, and writing. Using Rust’s safe concurrency primitives and asynchronous runtime capabilities (e.g., Tokio), the service guarantees thread-safe management of simultaneous requests from Prometheus. Memory segments are tracked with metadata to ensure correct mapping to Prometheus time series identifiers. Data encoding leverages Protocol Buffers with snappy compression to minimize network footprint. The backend includes mechanisms for bounding resource utilization and gracefully handling overload or failure scenarios.

The system offers a Grafana plugin that provides user-friendly dashboards for backend configuration and live monitoring metrics visualization. Users can configure connection parameters, monitor memory usage statistics (allocation counts, request latencies), and track health statuses in real time. Alerts can be defined in the Grafana interface for notifications on anomalous backend behavior or connectivity loss. Additionally, detailed query traces can be examined to correlate Prometheus query performance with remote memory backend responsiveness, facilitating operational troubleshooting.
Security is paramount; all communication between Prometheus and the Rust backend uses mutual TLS (

) to provide encrypted, authenticated channels, mitigating risks of data interception or unauthorized access. The backend enforces strict access control and credential validation before permitting memory operations. Sensitive data, such as authentication tokens or connection metadata, are securely stored and masked in logs. The system supports periodic certificate rotation and integration with organizational authentication policies (e.g., OAuth2, LDAP) to align with enterprise security standards.

Observability is achieved by exposing comprehensive telemetry data and logging from both Prometheus extensions and the Rust backend. Metrics such as allocation success rates, request latencies, error counts, and resource usage are available through Prometheus-compatible HTTP endpoints, enabling their ingestion into monitoring pipelines. The solution integrates distributed tracing (e.g.,

) to correlate request paths across components, revealing latency hotspots and failures within the remote memory calls. Logs are structured for easy aggregation and analysis, containing detailed context for operation tracing, which aids rapid debugging and system optimization.
The Prometheus instance shall connect to an external Rust-based memory backend using a dedicated Config API.
The Config API shall allow configuration updates dynamically without requiring Prometheus restart.
Secure connectivity shall be established via
over QUIC to ensure low-latency and reliable data exchange.
The Prometheus instance shall invoke backend APIs to allocate and release memory segments remotely.
Each allocated memory block shall be associated with unique metric identifiers to ensure proper referencing.
The backend shall manage concurrent allocation requests using safe Rust concurrency
images shall be automatically saved for reference or retraining.
Prometheus shall perform read and write operations on time-series data residing in the external backend.
The backend shall maintain data integrity during remote reads and writes, even under concurrent Prometheus queries.
schemas with Snappy compression for performance optimization.
Prometheus shall treat external memory data equivalently to local in-memory data for query evaluation.
Queried time-series data shall be fetched on demand via the backend to maintain real-time metric availability.
Data retrieval shall be optimized with chunk-level caching and revalidation mechanisms.
Grafana shall serve as the UI interface for setting up backend connections and monitoring metrics.
The user shall view, edit, or remove configurations from the Grafana-integrated panel connected via the Config API.
Configuration changes shall propagate immediately to update Prometheus connectivity and backend load behavior.
The Rust backend shall support scalable concurrent operations using asynchronous runtimes such as Tokio.
The system shall handle a minimum of 10,000 time-series operations per second without degradation.
The backend shall support horizontal scaling to handle growing Prometheus data workloads.
API endpoints shall remain stateless to facilitate load balancing across multiple backend instances.
Future integrations (e.g., multi-node Prometheus or cloud setups) shall require minimal reconfiguration.
The backend shall employ Rust’s ownership model for safety, preventing data races and memory leaks.
The system shall ensure data consistency and handle transient failures via retries with exponential backoff.
Crash recovery mechanisms shall reconstruct state using checkpoints or transaction logs.
All API communications shall be encrypted via mutual TLS (
Authentication tokens or certificates shall be validated before allowing Prometheus–backend communication.
Sensitive data in logs or memory shall be masked before persistence.
Prometheus and the Rust backend shall expose internal health metrics via HTTP endpoints for observability
Logs shall record allocation size, operation type, latency, and connection status for traceability.
) shall support cross-component latency monitoring and debugging.
Alert – A signal generated by Prometheus when a monitoring rule condition is triggered, typically forwarded to an alert manager or visualization tool for user action.
– A Prometheus component that handles alerts, grouping, silencing, and routing them to destinations like email, Slack, or PagerDuty.
Backend Daemon (Rust-based) – The external memory management server written in Rust that handles allocate, deallocate, read, and write operations for Prometheus through
Collector – A component or exporter that gathers metrics from an application or system and makes them available for scraping by Prometheus.
Config API – A runtime configuration interface designed to connect and manage Prometheus’s interaction with the external Rust backend system dynamically without restarts.
Distributed Memory – A configuration where memory resources are disaggregated from compute nodes and accessed remotely over the network to extend storage capacity and scalability.
Exporter – A service or process that exposes metrics from external sources, hardware, or applications in a Prometheus-compatible format.

(Google Remote Procedure Call) – A high-performance, language-agnostic framework for client-server communication using Protocol Buffers for defining structured APIs between Prometheus and the backend.
Grafana – The visualization layer used for monitoring and configuring the Prometheus-backend setup. It provides dashboards, live metrics, and alert management through a user-friendly web interface.
) – A security mechanism in which both client and server mutually authenticate during a TLS handshake, ensuring secure communication between Prometheus and the backend.
Prometheus – An open-source, cloud-native monitoring system that collects and stores time series metrics, queries data via
, and integrates with alerting and visualization tools.
(Prometheus Query Language) – A powerful query language used to retrieve, filter, and aggregate time series data stored by Prometheus.
QUIC – A transport protocol built on UDP designed to offer low-latency and secure data transfer, enhancing
communication performance between Prometheus and the external backend.
Remote Memory Service – The subsystem in the Rust backend exposed via
APIs that allows Prometheus to offload memory-intensive operations, acting as an extension of its native RAM.
Telemetry – System-generated data on performance, memory utilization, and connection statistics collected to monitor the health and activity of both Prometheus and the backend service.
Time Series Database (TSDB) – Prometheus’s internal storage engine for managing metrics over time. In this system, TSDB data can be extended to the backend using a hybrid memory architecture.
Tracing – A logging mechanism that tracks API requests and execution flow across distributed systems, helping identify latency bottlenecks and fault points during Prometheus-backend communication.
This Software Design Document (SDD) provides a comprehensive specification of the Memory as a Service (

) system architecture, design patterns, and implementation details. The document serves as the authoritative reference for software developers, system architects, quality assurance engineers, DevOps teams, and project managers involved in the development, deployment, and maintenance of the

system represents a dual-component architecture consisting of a standalone RESTful memory allocation service and an integrated Prometheus monitoring solution with external memory backend capabilities. This document captures the complete design philosophy, technical decisions, data models, API specifications, and operational workflows necessary for successful implementation.

The core memory service provides a RESTful API for dynamic RAM allocation and deallocation with configurable memory block sizes ranging from 1 MB to 10 GB. The system implements UUID-based allocation tracking and management, delivers real-time memory usage statistics and reporting, ensures thread-safe concurrent memory operations, supports customizable fill patterns for allocated memory, provides health monitoring and status endpoints, and implements automatic resource cleanup on deallocation.
The Prometheus integration component includes an external memory backend service implemented in Rust, supports dual-path data ingestion combining local and remote storage, utilizes

over QUIC communication protocol, enables time series data offloading capabilities, implements hybrid query execution merging local and remote data, provides a configuration API for runtime backend management, and integrates with Grafana dashboards for visualization.

System characteristics include high-performance asynchronous operations, zero-downtime service availability, cross-platform compatibility across Linux, macOS, and Windows via WSL, horizontal scalability for Prometheus integration, and comprehensive error handling and recovery mechanisms.

) is an innovative, high-performance system designed to provide programmatic control over system RAM allocation through well-defined APIs. Built using modern technologies including Rust for performance-critical components and Go for Prometheus extensions, the system delivers enterprise-grade memory management capabilities for testing, monitoring, and infrastructure validation scenarios.
The core memory allocation service forms the foundation of

as a lightweight REST API server built with Rust and the Axum web framework. This component handles on-demand memory allocation requests, maintains allocation state, and provides real-time statistics. The service leverages Rust's ownership model and type system to guarantee memory safety and prevent common vulnerabilities such as use-after-free and data races.

The Prometheus integration layer represents the second major component, extending Prometheus with external memory backend capabilities to enable large-scale time series data offloading. This Rust-based service communicates with Prometheus via

over QUIC, providing high-throughput, low-latency data ingestion and retrieval. The integration maintains backward compatibility with existing Prometheus deployments while adding distributed storage capabilities.

The memory allocation service implements UUID-based tracking where every allocation receives a universally unique identifier (UUID v4) for precise tracking and management. Configurable fill patterns support custom byte patterns ranging from 0 to 255 to simulate specific memory contents. Real-time statistics provide instant access to total allocated memory, active allocation count, and per-allocation details. Automatic cleanup through Rust's ownership system ensures automatic memory deallocation when allocations are removed. Concurrent safety is guaranteed through thread-safe operations using Arc and Mutex primitives. Built-in health endpoints enable monitoring and orchestration integration.

The Prometheus integration features dual-path ingestion with simultaneous writing to local TSDB and external memory backend. Hybrid queries enable transparent data merging from local and remote sources. Dynamic configuration allows runtime backend attachment and detachment without service restart. Fault tolerance is achieved through Write-Ahead Log (WAL) ensuring data durability during backend failures. Protocol Buffers provide efficient serialization with Snappy compression. Secure communication is established through mutual TLS (
API refers to Application Programming Interface, a set of protocols and tools for building software applications.
CRUD represents Create, Read, Update, Delete operations for basic data management.
HTTP is Hypertext Transfer Protocol, an application-layer protocol for distributed systems.
JSON stands for JavaScript Object Notation, a lightweight data interchange format.
denotes Memory as a Service, the system described in this document.
RAM is Random Access Memory, volatile computer memory.
REST means Representational State Transfer, an architectural style for distributed systems.
UUID represents Universally Unique Identifier, a 128-bit identifier standard.
TCP is Transmission Control Protocol, a connection-oriented transport protocol.
UDP stands for User Datagram Protocol, a connectionless transport protocol.
MB represents Megabyte, equal to 1,048,576 bytes.
GB is Gigabyte, equal to 1,073,741,824 bytes.
Arc is Atomic Reference Counter, a thread-safe shared ownership primitive.
Mutex represents Mutual Exclusion, a synchronization primitive ensuring exclusive access.
Ownership refers to Rust's memory management system without garbage collection.
Borrowing means temporary access to data without taking ownership. Async/Await is an asynchronous programming model for non-blocking operations.
Tokio is a production-ready asynchronous runtime for Rust.
Serde represents serialization/deserialization framework for Rust.
Cargo is Rust's package manager and build system.
RAII stands for Resource Acquisition Is Initialization, enabling automatic resource management.
TSDB is Time Series Database, optimized for time-stamped data.
WAL represents Write-Ahead Log, a durability mechanism for data persistence.
is Google Remote Procedure Call, a high-performance RPC framework.
QUIC means Quick UDP Internet Connections, a modern transport protocol over UDP.
refers to Protocol Buffers, a language-neutral data serialization format.
is Mutual TLS, providing two-way authentication using certificates.
Scrape is the process of collecting metrics from targets in Prometheus.
represents Prometheus Query Language, a functional query language for time series.
Exporter is a component that exposes metrics in Prometheus format.
TLS is Transport Layer Security, a cryptographic protocol for secure communication.
OAuth2 represents Open Authorization 2.0, an industry-standard authorization protocol.
X.509 is a standard for public key certificates. CA stands for Certificate Authority, an entity that issues digital certificates.

) is a dual-component distributed system designed to provide enterprise-grade memory management and metrics storage capabilities. The system operates as a collection of microservices that work together to deliver programmatic RAM allocation, real-time monitoring, and scalable time series data management.

Configurable fill patterns support custom byte patterns ranging from 0 to 255 to simulate specific memory contents. Real-time statistics provide instant access to total allocated memory, active allocation count, and per-allocation details. Automatic cleanup through Rust's ownership system ensures automatic memory deallocation when allocations are removed. Concurrent safety is guaranteed through thread-safe operations using Arc and Mutex primitives. Built-in health endpoints enable monitoring and orchestration integration.

Hybrid queries enable transparent data merging from local and remote sources. Dynamic configuration allows runtime backend attachment and detachment without service restart. Fault tolerance is achieved through Write-Ahead Log (WAL) ensuring data durability during backend failures. Protocol Buffers provide efficient serialization with Snappy compression. Architecture Pattern: Layered RESTful Microservice with Asynchronous Event-Driven Backend

system implements a sophisticated three-tier layered architecture that separates concerns across presentation, business logic, and data access layers. This separation enables independent scaling, testing, and evolution of each layer while maintaining clear interfaces and contracts.

The presentation layer handles all HTTP/REST API endpoints and client interactions. This layer is responsible for request parsing and validation including JSON deserialization using Serde, path parameter extraction, query string parsing, and content-type negotiation. Response formatting handles JSON serialization, HTTP status code selection, header configuration, and CORS handling when required. Error handling and recovery catches exceptions, formats error messages appropriately, and implements logging and tracing for observability.

The business logic layer contains all memory management services and core application logic. The allocation algorithm follows a structured process: validate size constraints, calculate byte size, allocate Vec<u8>, generate UUID v4, create metadata, and register the allocation. Deallocation logic validates UUID, looks up allocation, removes from registry, and drops memory with automatic cleanup. Statistics calculation computes total allocated bytes, active allocation count, age calculation, and per-allocation metadata. UUID generation and validation provides UUID v4 generation using cryptographically random values, format validation, and collision detection with statistical guarantee.
The data access layer manages state and physical memory. HashMap storage maps

timestamp. Thread synchronization uses Mutex for exclusive access control with RAII-based automatic unlocking and poisoning on panic for fail-safe behavior. Physical memory allocation uses Vec<u8> for direct system RAM allocation, maintains contiguous memory blocks, and implements zero-copy data management.

Separation of concerns isolates HTTP handling from business logic. Business logic remains independent of data storage. Clear boundaries enable independent testing of each layer. Single responsibility principle ensures each module has exactly one reason to change. Handlers only handle HTTP operations while services only implement logic. The storage layer only manages state. Dependency injection provides state to handlers via Axum extractors, enables testing with mock implementations, and reduces coupling between components. Fail-fast philosophy validates inputs at the boundary API layer, returns errors immediately without processing, and prevents invalid state propagation.

The system leverages Tokio's work-stealing scheduler for optimal performance. The async runtime manages a work-stealing thread pool with multiple threads that process incoming requests. Each HTTP request becomes an async task queued for execution. Tasks execute by parsing requests, acquiring mutex locks, updating state, releasing mutex locks, and formatting responses.
Thread safety is achieved through Arc<

> enabling cheap cloning with atomic reference counting. The Mutex<HashMap> provides lock acquisition that blocks until available. Critical sections perform read, modify, and write operations atomically. Automatic unlock occurs through RAII when the lock guard goes out of scope.

Vertical scaling strategy follows a growth path from small deployments with 2 GB RAM and 2 CPU cores handling approximately 1.5 GB allocations, to medium deployments with 16 GB RAM and 4 CPU cores handling approximately 14 GB allocations, up to large deployments with 128 GB RAM and 16 CPU cores handling approximately 120 GB allocations. Horizontal scaling for Prometheus integration enables multiple backend instances with load balancing. Each backend handles a subset of time series data. A coordination layer manages data distribution. Query aggregation combines results from multiple backends. Performance optimization techniques include connection pooling to reduce handshake overhead, request batching to group multiple operations, asynchronous I/O to prevent blocking operations, memory pre-allocation to reduce allocation overhead, and efficient serialization using zero-copy when possible.
The Write-Ahead Log (WAL) in Prometheus integration writes operations to durable storage before applying them. Operations can be replayed on recovery. Data loss is minimized in case of

breaker pattern prevents cascading failures by opening circuit after threshold failures, allowing time for recovery, and automatically closing when healthy. Retry mechanisms implement exponential backoff for transient failures, configurable retry limits, and idempotent operation design. Health checks provide liveness probes confirming the process is running, readiness probes indicating ability to serve traffic, and detailed health endpoint exposing component status.

Metrics collection exposes Prometheus-compatible endpoints. Key metrics include request count and latency, active allocation count and total size, error rates by type, and memory usage statistics. Distributed tracing uses

for trace propagation, span creation for operations, and context propagation across services. Structured logging implements JSON-formatted logs, correlation IDs for request tracking, log levels for filtering, and centralized log aggregation.
The Memory Allocation Module handles the core logic for allocating memory blocks and tracking allocations. This module is the heart of the
system, responsible for translating API requests into physical RAM allocations and maintaining metadata for each allocation.

The module validates allocation requests to ensure they meet system constraints. It allocates physical RAM using Rust's Vec<u8> type. The module generates unique identifiers using UUID v4 algorithm. It stores allocation metadata in the shared state HashMap. The module returns detailed allocation information to clients.
structure contains the allocation identifier as a
, actual allocated data as Arc<Vec<u8>>, and creation timestamp as
function is an async handler that receives State containing Arc<
. It returns Result with either success (
The algorithm executes the following steps in sequence. First, it receives the allocation request from the client. Second, it validates
to ensure 0 < size ≤ 10240. Third, it calculates
]. Fifth, it generates a UUID v4 identifier. Sixth, it creates a

struct instance. Seventh, it locks the mutex to gain exclusive access. Eighth, it inserts the allocation into HashMap. Ninth, it releases the mutex automatically. Tenth, it returns allocation details with 201 Created status.
if provided must be between 0 and 255 inclusive.
Fill pattern defaults to zero if not provided. Values outside 0-255 range are rejected. The pattern is applied uniformly across allocated memory.

Invalid size produces 400 Bad Request with message "Size must be greater than 0" or "Maximum allocation size is 10GB". Size exceeds limit produces 400 Bad Request with appropriate message. System out of memory produces 500 Internal Server Error with message "Failed to allocate memory". UUID generation failure (extremely rare) produces 500 Internal Server Error. Mutex poisoning (panic in another thread) produces 500 Internal Server Error.
Memory allocation time is O(n) where n equals

. For 100 MB allocation, typical time is 50-100ms. For 1 GB allocation, typical time is 500ms-1s. HashMap insertion averages O(1) complexity. Mutex contention is minimal due to quick operations. Lock hold time is typically under 1ms.

Rust ownership ensures no use-after-free vulnerabilities. Arc provides safe shared ownership across threads. Mutex prevents data races during concurrent access. Vec<u8> guarantees contiguous memory allocation. Automatic cleanup occurs via Drop trait when allocation removed.

The State Management Module maintains the in-memory state of all active allocations. It provides thread-safe access to allocation data and tracks the complete lifecycle of memory allocations from creation to deallocation.

The module stores allocation mappings in HashMap. It provides thread-safe access using Mutex. The module tracks allocation lifecycle from creation to removal. It calculates statistics on demand including total allocated memory and allocation count.
>>. This structure is wrapped in Arc for shared ownership across async tasks.

Insert operation has O(1) average complexity and is thread-safe via Mutex. Typical execution time is under 1ms. Lookup operation has O(1) average complexity, is thread-safe via Mutex, and typically executes in under 1ms. Remove operation has O(1) average complexity, is thread-safe via Mutex, and automatically frees memory. Iterate operation has O(n) complexity where n is allocation count, is thread-safe via Mutex, and is used for statistics calculation.
().unwrap(). It performs the operation such as insert, lookup, remove, or iterate. Lock automatically releases when allocations variable goes out of scope via RAII pattern.
> allows multiple owners with thread-safe reference counting. Reference count automatically decrements when Arc is dropped. Memory freed when last reference is dropped.
Mutex prevents data races by ensuring exclusive access. Only one thread can hold lock at a time. Attempting to acquire held lock blocks the thread.
Rust ownership prevents use-after-free. Borrowed references cannot outlive owner. Compiler enforces lifetime rules at compile time.
Mutex poisoning occurs when a thread panics while holding lock. Poisoned mutex can be recovered using lock().
state and continue operation. Poisoning indicates serious error requiring investigation.
The API Handler Module processes HTTP requests and formats responses. It serves as the presentation layer, translating between HTTP protocol and internal business logic.

The module parses incoming requests extracting path parameters, query strings, and JSON bodies. It validates request data ensuring type safety and constraint compliance. The module invokes business logic delegating to appropriate service functions. It formats responses serializing data to JSON and setting HTTP status codes. The module handles errors catching exceptions and returning user-friendly messages.
creates new memory allocation, validates size and fill pattern, generates UUID, stores allocation, and returns allocation details with 201 Created.
retrieves all allocations, calculates statistics, returns summary with allocation list, and uses 200 OK status.
looks up specific allocation by UUID, validates UUID format, returns allocation details if found, and returns 404 Not Found if missing.
validates UUID format, removes allocation from registry, automatically frees memory, and returns 204 No Content on success.
removes all allocations, clears HashMap, frees all memory, and returns 200 OK with count.
returns service status, requires no authentication, always returns 200 OK, and includes service name and status.

HTTP request enters system. Axum router matches route pattern. Request extraction occurs for Path parameters, Json body, and State dependency. Validation checks parameter types and constraint validation. Business logic execution follows. Response formatting serializes to JSON and sets headers. HTTP response returns to client.
CREATED, Json(response))). Error responses use tuple (

Type validation occurs through Serde deserialization. Invalid JSON structure is automatically rejected. Type mismatches produce 400 Bad Request. Constraint validation checks business rules such as size limits. Custom validation logic is implemented in handlers. Violations produce descriptive error messages. UUID validation uses
() function. Invalid format produces 400 Bad Request. Non-existent UUIDs produce 404 Not Found.
The Monitoring Module provides health checks and system statistics. It enables external monitoring systems to track service health and performance metrics.

The module reports health status for liveness and readiness probes. It provides memory usage statistics including total allocated and active allocations. The module exposes allocation inventory listing all active allocations. It supports future performance metrics including request rates and latency histograms.

returns Json<Value>. Response includes status field set to "healthy", service field set to "memory-as-a-service", and timestamp for request time. HTTP status is always 200 OK. Response time is typically under 5ms. No authentication is required.
count of allocations, and allocations as Vec<
The algorithm locks HashMap for safe access, iterates through all allocations, sums
, calculates age for each allocation, collects allocation details, releases lock automatically, formats response, and returns JSON.

gauge. Request rate tracking includes requests per second, average request duration, error rate percentage, and success rate percentage. Memory allocation patterns track average allocation size, median allocation size, percentiles at 95th and 99th, and allocation size distribution. Performance histograms include allocation latency buckets, query latency buckets, and deallocation latency buckets.

represents a single memory allocation block. It contains metadata including unique identifier, size information, creation timestamp, and reference to actual allocated memory. The lifetime extends from allocation until deallocation or server restart. This entity is internal and not exposed directly through the API.
represents public view of an allocation. It is used for API responses and contains metadata without actual memory data. This entity is serializable to JSON. It includes computed fields like
represents aggregated statistics about all allocations. It is computed on-demand and not persisted. This entity provides system-wide view of memory usage and includes list of all allocations.
. Each allocation has exactly one UUID. UUID provides fast HashMap lookup.

Creation occurs when client sends POST /allocate request. Allocation receives unique UUID. Memory is physically allocated. Metadata stored in HashMap. Client receives allocation details. Active state means allocation exists in HashMap. Memory remains allocated. Allocation is

via API. Statistics include this allocation. Memory stays resident in RAM. Deallocation happens when client sends DELETE request. Allocation removed from HashMap. Memory automatically freed via Drop trait. UUID becomes invalid. Statistics no longer include allocation.
All data resides in RAM with no disk persistence. Data is lost on process termination. Recovery is not possible after restart. This design provides maximum performance.
> serves as the primary storage. Key is

Volatile storage means data is lost on process termination. No persistence to disk occurs. Recovery after crash is not possible. Thread-safe access is protected by Mutex. Multiple threads can safely access. Concurrent modifications are serialized. Shared access across async tasks via Arc. Reference counting manages lifetime. Automatic cleanup when last reference dropped. Dynamic growth and shrinkage follows allocation and deallocation. HashMap resizes automatically. Memory usage scales with allocations.
wrapped in Arc. Inside is HashMap wrapped in Mutex. HashMap entries map UUID keys to
contains metadata and Vec<u8> data. Vec<u8> is actual allocated memory block.
